chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected peripheral arterial disease?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Assess for peripheral arterial disease if the person: 
    • Has symptoms suggestive of peripheral arterial disease, or
    • Has diabetes, non-healing wounds on the legs or feet, or unexplained leg pain, or
    • Is being considered for interventions to the leg or foot, or
    • Needs to use compression hosiery.
  • Assess people with suspected peripheral arterial disease by: 
    • Asking about:
      • Whether symptoms are acute or chronic.
      • Location and timing of symptoms.
      • The presence and severity of possible symptoms of acute limb ischaemia, intermittent claudication, and critical limb ischaemia. For more information, see the section on Features of acute limb ischaemia and Features of intermittent claudication and critical limb ischaemia. 
      • Impact of symptoms on work, daily living, and socialising.
      • Risk factors (for example atrial fibrillation for acute ischaemia, smoking for peripheral arterial disease). 
      • Family history of thrombosis.
    • Examining: 
      • The legs and feet for ulceration, temperature differences between the legs, muscle atrophy, and skin changes (for example thin, shiny skin, discolouration, dependent rubor and elevation pallor, tissue loss on the heel or between the toes, hair loss). 
      • Femoral, popliteal, and foot pulses. 
      • Capillary refill time (although this may not be reliable).
      • The cardiovascular system (including for arterial bruits — femoral, aortic, carotid).
  • Assess people with suspected peripheral arterial disease by measuring the ankle brachial pressure index (ABPI). This should be undertaken by an experienced operator using validated equipment.
    • If an experienced operator using validated equipment is not able to detect an ankle pulse on Doppler, consider the possibility of acute limb ischaemia (see Features of acute limb ischaemia) and seek immediate advice from a vascular specialist. 
  • With the person resting and supine (if possible):
    • Record systolic blood pressure with an appropriately sized cuff in both arms and in the posterior tibial, dorsalis pedis, and, where possible, peroneal arteries.
    • Take measurements manually using a Doppler probe of suitable frequency in preference to an automated system.
    • Calculate the index in each leg by dividing the highest ankle pressure by the highest arm pressure.
  • An ABPI ratio of less than 0.9 indicates the presence of peripheral arterial disease (with some classifications using a threshold value of less than 0.5 for critical limb ischaemia), but a resting ABPI of more than 0.9 does not mean that peripheral arterial disease is not present. 
    • If lower extremity artery disease is clinically suspected, a normal ABPI does not exclude the diagnosis — if there is any doubt about the diagnosis, seek advice from a vascular surgeon. 
    • If the ABPI is high (1.4 or more), consider the possibility of peripheral arterial disease, particularly if the person has diabetes. Do not exclude a diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease in people with diabetes based on a normal or raised ankle brachial pressure index alone. 
      • Take into account other symptoms and signs, and seek specialist advice if unsure of the diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
When to assess for peripheral arterial disease

  • This recommendation is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Peripheral arterial disease: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012b]. 

Approach to assessment

  • An evidence review for NICE found no evidence comparing clinical assessment with ankle brachial pressure index (ABPI). The guideline development group (GDG) were of the opinion that the diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease should be made on the basis of history, examination and ABPI measurement, with the caveat that clinical judgement should be used as even this combination is not always accurate [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012].

History and examination

  • The features of history and examination for people with suspected peripheral arterial disease are based on the NICE guideline Peripheral arterial disease: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012b], subsequent North American guidelines on lower extremity peripheral artery disease [Gerhard-Herman et al, 2017], international consensus guidelines on chronic limb-threatening ischaemia [Conte et al, 2019] and expert opinion in review articles [Wennberg, 2013; Kullo and Rooke, 2016; Santistevan, 2017; Barraclough and Bradbury, 2018; Farber, 2018; Morley et al, 2018; Firnhaber and Powell, 2019]. 

Measuring ABPI

  • This recommendation reflects the NICE guideline Peripheral arterial disease: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012b], and is based on consensus from the experience of the NICE GDG, who noted that [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012]:  
    • The person should be supine where possible when measuring ABPI because it equalises the blood pressure in the brachial and lower limb arteries.
    • It is important to choose an appropriately sized cuff for the lower limb because if the cuff size is incorrect it may result in an incorrect ABPI measurement.
    • The recommended frequency range of the Doppler probe to measure peripheral vessels is 7–10 MHz.
    • An attempt should be made to measure all three arteries in the foot as some people (for example those with diabetes) may only have a pulse in the peroneal artery.
    • ABPI should be measured in people with tissue loss (ulceration and/or gangrene) or painful limbs, but it should be noted that falsely elevated ankle pressures can be obtained in people with renal failure or diabetes.
  • More recent European, North American, and global guidelines also recommend measuring the ankle-brachial pressure index in people with suspected peripheral arterial disease [Conte et al, 2015; Aboyans et al, 2018; Conte et al, 2019].
  • Expert opinion from previous reviewers of this CKS topic emphasized the need for an experienced operator using validated equipment to measure the ABPI to avoid errors or false diagnosis of absent Doppler signals. European guidelines also note that good training is mandatory [Aboyans et al, 2018]. 

Consideration of acute limb ischaemia

  • Expert opinion in an evidence summary describes an absence of pulse in the lower extremity on Doppler ultrasound as a sign of acute limb ischaemia [BMJ Best Practice, 2018]. In this situation the ABPI cannot be calculated [Santistevan, 2017].
    • Recommended standards for reports dealing with lower extremity ischaemia [Rutherford et al, 1997] and review articles [Jaffery et al, 2011; McNally and Univers, 2018] state that an inaudible arterial Doppler signal is a sign of a threatened limb, which at best is salvageable if promptly treated and at worst is irreversibly damaged.
    • Expert opinion in review articles advises consultation with a vascular surgery unit, on an emergency basis, in the absence of palpable pulses or audible arterial Doppler signal [Brearley, 2013; Santistevan, 2017]. CKS has advised seeking immediate specialist advice on this basis of this and expert opinion from previous reviewers of this CKS topic which suggests that if symptoms and signs are also taken into account and indicate the possibility of acute limb ischaemia, immediate specialist advice should be sought as emergency referral may be required.

Interpreting ABPI values

  • This recommendation is based on guidelines from NICE [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012] and the European Society of Cardiology and European Society for Vascular Surgery [Aboyans et al, 2018]. 
  • In terms of sensitivity and negative predictive values, an ABPI of less than 0.9 is recommended as the best indicator for peripheral arterial disease [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012]. ABPI of this value has a 75% sensitivity and 86% specificity to diagnose lower extremity artery disease (lower in people with diabetes) [Aboyans et al, 2018]. The NICE full guideline states that 'various definitions and classifications often use ABPI as an indicator of disease severity, with the use of a threshold value for ABPI of below 0.5 for critical limb ischaemia and less than 0.9 for peripheral arterial disease'. It notes, however, that some people (for example those with diabetes mellitus, who may have significantly impaired circulation, non-healing ulceration or infection and be at high risk of limb loss) do not always match these definitions of ABPI [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2012]. 
    • The recommendation to seek advice if there is doubt about the diagnosis is based on expert opinion in review articles on peripheral arterial disease [Firnhaber and Powell, 2019] and chronic limb-threatening ischaemia [Barraclough and Bradbury, 2018]. 
      • Exercise ABPI testing may be used for people in whom the diagnosis is uncertain on the basis of examination and resting ABPI (for example normal resting ABPI despite exertional claudication) [Conte et al, 2015; Firnhaber and Powell, 2019]. 
      • Measurement of ABPI may not be as useful in chronic limb-threatening ischaemia as for intermittent claudication and should not be used to determine referral in primary care if chronic limb-threatening ischaemia cannot be confidently excluded on the basis of vascular history and clinical examination. Signals may be difficult to hear and could be from collateral vessels, and pressure measurements may be falsely raised because the arterial wall is calcified [Barraclough and Bradbury, 2018].
    • European guidelines note that ABPI values of more than 1.4 may indicate arterial stiffening (medial arterial calcification) which is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events and is more common with increased age and in people with diabetes or chronic kidney disease [Aboyans et al, 2018]. The NICE guideline on Peripheral arterial disease: diagnosis and management added a recommendation in 2018 that diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease should not be excluded in people with diabetes based on a normal or raised ankle brachial pressure index alone. Hardening of the arteries in people with diabetes and peripheral arterial disease may result in a normal or raised index [NICE, 2012b]. 
      • CKS has pragmatically made the recommendation to consider the possibility of peripheral arterial disease if the ABPI is high (1.4 or more) taking into account other symptoms and signs and to seek specialist advice if unsure of the diagnosis.
      • A European guideline on the diagnosis and treatment of peripheral arterial diseases mentions toe-brachial index, Doppler waveform analysis, or pulse voulme recording as alternative tests that may be necessary in people with incompressible ankle arteries or ABPI of more than 1.4 [Aboyans et al, 2018].
